utterances: People that are going back to Cuba more than once a year is not humanitarian.
They're essentially residing in Cuba.
They have some type of business practice that they've established by taking goods back and forth.
They're called mulas.
The Miami to Cuba mules carry goods and cash.
At least for some Cuban-Americans, it's a legal end-run around the trade embargo.
And essentially, they charge per pound or they charge per package of things that they take to Cuba.
So they've established a business practice of travelling to the island back and forth.
That is not the purpose of the regulations.
That's a business practice and that should be illegal.
There are others, though, who say this is the kind of thing unrestricted travel and remittances were intended to accomplish.

By traveling frequently to the island and helping - maybe even investing - in businesses run by family members, Cuban-Americans are helping spread the kind of free-market activity long-sought by the U.S.
Those who favor engagement between the U.S.
and Cuba say the next steps should include lifting all restrictions on travel to the island and allowing U.S.
visitors to use credit cards there.
Greg Allen, NPR News, Miami.
And you're listening to MORNING EDITION from NPR News.

Well, let's remind listeners this goes back to Ambassador Joseph Wilson, who was assigned by the Bush administration to go over and look into reports that the government of Niger had sold yellow cake - that a precursor to a uranium fuel for nuclear weapons - to the Iraqis.
He came back with the conclusion that this was not likely to have happened at all.
Indeed, almost certainly did not happen.
Yet the assertion that it had happened ended up still in the president's State of the Union Address one year.
He cited British sources.
But anyway, Ambassador Wilson then wrote an op-ed in the newspapers that said the Bush administration was twisting facts that it knew to be wrong to make its case on Iraq.
Then a few days after that the name of Ambassador Wilson's wife, Valerie Plame, was leaked to the news media as a CIA agent.
She was an undercover operative.
The allegation was that her name was leaked to get back at Joe Wilson for going after the Bush administration.
Yeah.
Excellent.
That's a great summation.
It all started out with those 16 words in the State of the Union from 2003.
And then Joe Wilson wrote something in the New York Times which basically said, listen, you're being misled on this, everybody.
And then within a - actually it was eight days later, Robert Novak had a column written where he outed Valerie Plame as being the wife of this gentleman, Joseph Wilson.
And from then it actually - there was a lag time between when that story came out and when people really started to get upset about it.
So it took, you know, a good four, five, six months before we really learned in D.C.
to get exorcised by this case.
Hm-hmm.
And this is when Patrick Fitzgerald was brought on.
And it became a cause lib celeb here in Washington, D.C., where everybody was sure that we were either going to get Karl Rove investigated in this case or we were going to see Dick Cheney brought in.

We're talking about the Scooter Libby case.
I guess we should stop calling it the Valerie Plame case.
The trial begins here in Washington, D.C.
tomorrow.

And lest we leave our listeners in limbo, those who have not noticed that this case was resolved, it turned out that the leakee - the leaker - was not initially Scooter Libby, without even initially Dick Cheney or even initially the President of the United States.

Yeah, Richard Armitage, who was not seen as being one of the insiders in the White House administration at all.
